How Not To Steal A Site Design

05 Jul 2001

\nOur good friends at Proxima Consulting\nseem to have problems deciding what to put on their site. Poor lambs.\n

\n

\nThey also seem to have had problems with coming up with an effective\nuser experience.\n

\n

\nSo, in the best tradition of dumb people everywhere, they stole it. All.\nWords, images, layout, sitemap down to a URL level. Everything.\n

\n

\nWhich would have been fine (in a 'not' sense) except that they stole\nit from one of the better UK CED and SI agencies, Oyster\n

\n

\n...who found it when one of their staff was doing some research last weekend. The\nonly changes Proxima had made seems to have been a crude\nsearch and replace on the Oyster name, even claiming that Proxima\nhad merged with companies who had in fact merged with Oyster.\n

\n

\nSince being called on it, Proxima have pulled the entire site beyond\nthe Flash intro. So skipping the intro means you also skip the entire\nsite. Nice.\n

\n

\nFortunately, Google has a cached copy. Here are a couple of samples:\n

\n
    \n
  • \nProxima's jobs page\nand\nOyster's job page.\n
    • \n
  • \nOyster's history (note the KBW merger info) and\napproach -v-\nProxima's approach (who say that they merged with KBW).\n
    • \n
\n

Oyster took a copy of the offending site and contacted Proxima, which may explain the Proxima site disappearance. I hear that Oyster aren't going to sue... at the moment

\n

Can you imagine being the person responsible, and the meeting held at Proxima to consider his or her future... Are they selling tickets?
